Z violino uresničuje otroške sanje
07 Nov 2019, 06:00 by Lea Hedžet

20-letna Tjaša Klanac iz Zarečja pri Ilirski Bistrici je študentka drugega letnika Univerze za glasbo in upodabljajočo umetnost v Gradcu, kjer je februarja letos postala tudi članica Dunajskega mladinskega orkestra.



Tjaša Klanac se zelo uspešno uveljavlja v Avstriji. Foto: Jana Gombač

Tjaša Klanac si rada postavlja visoke cilje, ki jih tudi zelo uspešno uresničuje. Že v osnovni in srednji šoli je zmagovala na državnih in mednarodnih tekmovanjih, kot solistka in kot članica komornih skupin. A njen glavni cilj ni prejemati nagrade, pač pa dobro igrati. Njen glavni navdih je glasba sama.
V violino se je zaljubila kot majhna deklica, ko je v televizijskem prenosu gledala poletni koncert Dunajskih filharmonikov, ves čas nepremično stala pred zaslonom in zavzeto poslušala. Na koncu se je priklonila in zbranemu domačemu občinstvu naznanila, da bo nekoč tudi sama tako igrala. In od takrat “dela na tem” … Najprej se je vpisala na domačo glasbeno šolo v Ilirski Bistrici, nadaljevala je na Glasbeni šoli Vič-Rudnik in potem še na ljubljanskem Konservatoriju za glasbo in balet. In že od vsega začetka je vedela, da bo violina igrala glavno vlogo v njenem življenju. Zato je zelo hvaležna staršem, ki so jo štiri leta vozili v Ljubljano na ure violine, pa tudi profesorjem: Tina Balazs ji je dala osnove, Jernej Brence pa je njeno igro povzdignil na višjo raven.
V rubriki Primorski glasbeni talenti, ki jo pripravljamo v sodelovanju z Radiem Koper, predstavljamo mlade primorske glasbenike, ki se ukvarjajo s klasično glasbo in dosegajo opazne uspehe doma in na tujem. Gostja tokratne istoimenske rubrike v oddaji Glasbeni abonma, ki bo na sporedu drevi ob 20. uri, bo violinistka Tjaša Klanac, ki jo boste ob pogovoru lahko slišali še v izvedbi izjemno zahtevne Brahmsove Sonate št. 1 v G-duru in skladbi Beli konjiVladimirja Batiste ob klavirski spremljavi Beate Brarcza.
Na srednji šoli je doživela največji preskok: “Naučila sem se tudi delati, ne le igrati.” Zato uspehi niso izostali; kot solistka in komorna glasbenica je prejela več nagrad na domačih in mednarodnih tekmovanjih; med njimi so Zlatne stepenice (prvo mesto), Temsig (zlata plaketa s Triom Liberté) ter Antonio Salieri (prva nagrada z istim triom, ki se je junija lani predstavil celo na dunajskem festivalu Eunic-Fest).
V zadnjem času se je Tjaša pridružila še komornemu orkestru Camerata Laibach, s katerim je tudi zmagala na mednarodnem tekmovanju v Sarajevu, ter Obalnemu komornemu orkestru. Z obema je nastopila tudi kot solistka. Ob tem pa se je redno udeleževala mojstrskih tečajev pri priznanih violinskih pedagogih, kot so Igor Ozim, Wonji Kim, Elisabeth Kropfitsch, Stefan Milenković … pa tudi Maighréad McCrann, sicer koncertna mojstrica simfoničnega orkestra avstrijske radiotelevizije, ki je oktobra lani postala njena profesorica v Gradcu. Priti do nje je bil velik podvig, saj je morala Tjaša opraviti avdicijo, na kateri sta bila izmed 90 kandidatov izbrana le dva študenta. Zdaj je zelo srečna, saj se s profesorico odlično razume, izbrala si jo je za vzornico; tudi Tjaša bi rada nekoč postala koncertna mojstrica kakega velikega orkestra, pa tudi profesorica. Ob tem si želi imeti še dovolj časa za solistično in komorno muziciranje. Kot študentka avstrijske univerze ima že danes možnost igrati v različnih avstrijskih orkestrih in z dunajskim mladinskim je že koncertirala v Wiener Konzerthaus in v sloviti dvorani Musikverein, ki jo vsi poznamo po novoletnih koncertih. Poleg tega se želi izpopolnjevati še drugod, saj akademija najboljšim študentom krije šolnine za razne tečaje pri uglednih violinskih pedagogih z vsega sveta. To pa je najboljši možni način za spoznavanje morebitnih profesorjev pri nadaljnjem študiju. In Tjaša si želi magisterij opravljati v Berlinu.
O daljni prihodnosti pa še ne želi razmišljati. Raje si pušča odprta vsa vrata. Rada sodeluje pri vseh projektih, h katerim jo povabijo (poleti je celo kot koncertna mojstrica Slovenskega nacionalnega mladinskega orkestra spremljala Vlada Kreslina v Križankah). Zanjo je trenutno najpomembnejše stalno izpopolnjevanje v igranju violine, da bo lahko zaigrala vse tiste, tudi najtežje skladbe, ki so ji najbolj všeč in ki si jih najbolj želi: “Ko znaš dobro igrati, lahko igraš karkoli in kjerkoli.”
text:
With a violin, she fulfills a childhood dream
07 Nov 2019, 06:00 by Lea Hedget

20-year-old Tjaša Klanac from Zarec near Ilirska Bistrica is a sophomore at the University of Music and Performing Arts in Graz, where she became a member of the Vienna Youth Orchestra in February this year.



Tjaša Klanac is very successfully established in Austria. Photo by Jana Gombac

Tjaša Klanac likes to set high goals, which she also very successfully accomplishes. Already in elementary and high school, she has won national and international competitions as a soloist and as a member of chamber groups. But its main goal is not to win prizes, but to play well. Her main inspiration is the music itself.
She fell in love with the violin as a little girl as she watched the Vienna Philharmonic's summer concert on television, stood motionless in front of the screen and listened intently. In the end, she bowed and announced to the assembled domestic audience that she would once play the same. And since then she has been "working on it" ... She first enrolled at the home school of music in Ilirska Bistrica, continued at the Vič-Rudnik School of Music and then at the Conservatory of Music and Ballet in Ljubljana. And from the beginning, she knew that the violin would play a major role in her life. Therefore, she is very grateful to her parents, who drove her to violin lessons for four years in Ljubljana, as well as to her professors: Tina Balazs gave her the basics and Jernej Brence raised her play to a higher level.
The Primorska musical talents section, prepared in cooperation with Radio Koper, presents young coastal musicians who are engaged in classical music and have achieved notable successes at home and abroad. The guest of the section of the same name in the program Music subscription, scheduled to air at 8 pm, will be violinist Tjaša Klanac, who will be able to hear you during the performance of Brahms's extremely demanding Sonata no. 1 in G major and the song White horses by Vladimir Batista with piano accompaniment by Beate Brarz.
She made the biggest leap in high school: “I learned how to work, not just play.” Therefore, successes were not lost; as a soloist and chamber musician, she has won several awards at domestic and international competitions; these include the Golden Stairs (first place), Temsig (gold plaque with the Liberté Trio) and Antonio Salieri (first prize with the same trio, which even appeared at the Eunic-Fest festival in June last year).
Recently, Tjaša joined the Camerata Laibach Chamber Orchestra, with which she also won the Sarajevo International Competition and the Coastal Chamber Orchestra. With both, she also performed as a soloist. In addition, she regularly attended master classes with renowned violin educators such as Igor Ozim, Wonji Kim, Elisabeth Kropfitsch, Stefan Milenković… as well as Maighréad McCrann, otherwise a concertmaster of the Austrian Radio and Television Symphony Orchestra, which became its professor in Graduation last October. . Getting there was a huge feat, as Tjaša had to audition, with only two students selected from the 90 candidates. She is very happy now that she has a great understanding with the professor, she has chosen her as a role model; Tjaša would also like to become a concertmaster of some great orchestra, as well as a professor. He also wants to have plenty of time for solo and chamber music. As a student at the University of Austria, she already has the opportunity to play in various Austrian orchestras, and with the Vienna Youth she has already performed in Wiener Konzerthaus and in the famous Musikverein Hall, which we all know for New Year's concerts. In addition, he wants to further his studies as the Academy covers the best students with tuition fees for various courses from renowned violin educators from around the world. This, however, is the best possible way to get to know potential professors in your further studies. And Tjaša wants to pursue a master's degree in Berlin.
However, he does not want to think about the distant future. He prefers to leave all the doors open. She likes to participate in any projects she is invited to (in the summer she even accompanied the Government of Kreslin in Križanke as a concertmaster of the Slovenian National Youth Orchestra). At the moment, she is most important in her continuous training in playing the violin so that she can play all those, even the hardest, songs that she likes best and that she wants most: "When you can play well, you can play anything and anywhere."
